RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

TYSON FRESH MEATS INC. LOUISA COUNTY, IOWA

1)   Accident Release Prevention Program and Emergency Response Policy
It is the policy of the Tyson, inc. Louisa County, Iowa facility management to implement the requirements of this Risk Management Program (RMP) in accordance with the USEPA regulations under 40 CFR Part 68 and with the corresponding regulations under OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) program.  The objective is to minimize the risk of a release of a hazardous material and if a release occurs, to minimize the potential impact to Tyson employees, the public and the environment.  This objective will be accomplished by utilizing general good operating procedures, providing appropriate training to all employees, and coordinating response activities, as necessary, with the local emergency response providers. This plan covers all Tyson owned activities at this facility.
Tyson's management is committed to providing the resources necessary to implement this policy.

2)  Facility Description
Tyson operates a hog slaughter and processing facility at this location.  Hogs are trucked to the facility, slaughtered and fabricated.  Tyson operates rendering systems to produce crax, lard, grease, and other rendered products.  Support operations include a wastewater treatment system, truck repair facilities, cold storage, an analytical laboratory, and administrative offices.
Two chemicals are utilized at the facility in sufficient quantities to be subject to the requirements of 40 CFR Part 68.  These chemicals are chlorine and ammonia.  Chlorine is used as a disinfectant and to treat wastewater and ammonia is used as a refrigerant throughout the facility.


3)  General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps
The Louisa County, Iowa facility is governed by a set of OSHA and USEPA regulations that require planning and facility activities intended to prevent a release of hazardous material, or

if a release inadvertently occurs, to minimize the consequences of a release to the employees of the facility, the public and to the environment.  These regulations include:
* 40 CFR Part 68, Accidental Release Prevention
* 40 CFR Part 112, Spill Prevention, Control and Countermeasure
* 40 CFR Part 264, Hazardous Waste Contingency Plan
* 29 CFR Part 119, Process Safety Management
* 40 CFR Part 302, Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA)
The key concepts in Tyson's release prevention program are employee participation, appropriate design and maintenance of equipment, and appropriate training of all employees.  Tyson has developed and documented these elements in their process safety management plan (PSM).  The PSM plan is incorporated with this document by reference.
Employee participation in the release prevention program is encouraged and supported by Tyson management.  Key personnel are responsible for conducting and implementing the findings from the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) for the ammonia and chlorine systems.  Tyson employees are also members of the facility emergency response team.
Tyson policy is to construct all new equipment, systems, and facilities to ensure the appropriate safety and release prevention systems are included from the beginning of each project.  Tyson maintains a computerized program of maintenance activities to ensure that key systems are maintained appropriately to minimize the risk of a release.
Tyson is committed to providing appropriate training to all employees regarding safety procedures.  Each new employee is provided comprehensive safety training during their initial orientation for the facility.  In addition, Tyson conducts regularly scheduled safety training for all employees each year.  Additional training is provided to maintenance personnel for the systems they are responsible for.  Members of Tyson's emergency response team receive annual training to ensure that response actions are promptly and safel

y completed.

4)  Five Year Accident History
Tyson has had a release of ammonia from the Louisa County, Iowa facility on 9/08/2002 in which about 50 people were evacuated from their homes as a precautionary measure when an ammonia line was leaking in the engine room. Most of the ammonia was contained within the boundrys of the facility.

5)  Emergency Response Program
Tyson has personnel trained in emergency response at the facility 24 hours per day, seven days per week.  These personnel receive annual training on emergency procedures and response techniques.
Emergency Contact information within the RMP contains phone numbers for the following purposes and use by EPA:

Emergency Contact phone: the emergency contact number provided for EPAA?s use is a direct line to the office of the Emergency Contact person for TysonA?s Louisa Co. facility during normal business hours.  If there is an immediate need and the Emergency Contact is not available at this number, EPA should then make use of the 24-hour phone provided and request to speak with him. 
24-hour phone: outside of normal business hours, EPA is to call the 24-hour number provided.  The 24-hour phone number provided here is to the facilityA?s 24-hour manned guard station, within the guard station is a phone-list.  In the event of an emergency the security guard is trained to make calls and inform the proper facility management of the emergency at hand.  The facility will initiate training with their security personnel that from this point forward that phone will now be for two-way use.  In effect Security will be trained that this phone number is available for use by EPA for after-hours calls to TysonA?s designated Louisa Co. facility emergency contact in the event of an emergency situation at the facility.

6)  Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Tyson completes a thorough review of the ammonia system and chlorine system each time a design change is implemented.  Tyson is committed to using these methods to identif
y and implement ways to improve the safety of these systems.
